title: Git Notes
text:
Terminology

A project is a folder containing files and folders.
A repository (or repo) is a project version controlled using Git.
A local repository is a repository stored on a computer.
A remote repository is a repository stored on a hosting service.

title: Setup
text:
Install Git
Download the executable from here

title: Setup
text:
Update Git
Download the most recent installer, or run
git update-git-for-windows

title: Setup
text:
Version
To get the current version number
git version
Alternatively you can use git -v or git --version.

title: Setup
text:
Setup Identity
To set up user name and email address use the commands
git config --global user.name "<your name>"
git config --global user.email "<your email>"
You have to do this only once. You can change these settings any time.

title: Setup
text:
Setup Default Branch Name
By default Git creates a initial branch called master. To set a different name, for example main, run
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

title: Setup
Local Repo Basics
text:
Start Version Control
To start version control in the current directory use
Initialize a Git repository and set the name for the initial branch to be <branch_name>.

title: Local Repo Basics
section: Adding files to the staging area
text:
Adding files to the staging area
Add one file to the staging area
git add <filename>
Add multiple files to the staging area.
git add <filename> <filename> ...
Add all the files in the working directory that have been edited or changed to the staging area.
git add -A

title: Local Repo Basics
text:
Making a commit
It’s important to note that commit is both a verb and a noun. In Git, the verb to commit means to save something, and the noun (a commit) means a version of our project. So, to make a commit means to save a version of a project.
To create a new commit with a commit message.
git commit -m “<message>”

title: References
text: Pro Git by Scott Chacon and Ben Straub
